ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A
None

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how hard it is to motivate creative working 1. on your own (as opposed to collaboratively) and 2. in a class setting. I'm not sure if playwriting alone will ultimately be for me, but I'm so glad that I took this class, found out, and wrote a play in the process! I learned how to open up my imagination and approach the inner judgments which kept me from writing what I really wanted to write about.
I gained so much insight into the practice of playwriting. Also tools, resources, and strategies for letting go of the inner critic. It was wonderful.
how to write a play and develop consistency and practices to better facilitate my ideas or generate ideas

An amazing class that really reinforced my confidence in my own writing abilities. I never thought I would be able to write a full length play, but Debs guidance makes it so that its not only possible, but you also enjoy the entire process.

This course helped me fight my inner critic and write creatively. We learned a lot about play development, creating a voice for our characters, the formation of conflict and comedy, and most importantly, how to bring what we want to write about to life.

Reading plays and reading my peers' scenes helped me gain confidence in my writing and figure out how I want to use my words. I also am walking away with countless "fill in the blanks" and ideas and inspiration for future writing!
I learned to get rid of the inner critic when playwriting. Ultimately, I learned to be a PLAYWRIGHT! Deb is absolutely amazing and we learn the "logical but illogical poetry" of writing a play.
I learned a lot about the craft and process of playwriting.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: Opportunities for writing in-class, sharing and discussing work, presenting on plays (the syllabus is designed by the students based on which plays we want to read and talk about), clear feedback and available instructor, lots of fun. Weakness: Sometimes a tad disorganized and the "no negative feedback" rule is inspiring but sometimes can lead to less thoughtful comments from classmates.
No weaknesses.

This course was really great at meeting everyone at his or her own level. The assignments were great tools for development and provided space for people to work past their inner critic and find their voice.

Reading scenes aloud and designating time for in-class writing was wonderful. Checking in at the beginning of each class was great, too, and something I really appreciated during an online semester. I always wished we could discuss the weekly assigned plays more in-depth, so a few more minutes for this each class would have been appreciated. But I think everything about the class
Strengths: Everything. The class meets a total of 4 hours a week, but with Deb and the students, the class flies by with excitement, joy, and positivity.
I really enjoyed this course! Students got to choose all the plays that we read, and it was very helpful to be able to share scenes in class.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Usually in this class, students switch spots in the room, which was accomplished by switching spots on the computer screen. Playwriting, and really most creative classes, is always difficult to share over Zoom. But overallespecially with writing breaks during classI think that it went quite well!
I felt that this class transferred really well to the virtual format. It gave me a lot of joy and showed me how the practice of writing can be cultivated under any circumstances.
I thought that the engagement was the best possible considering the Covid-19 restraints.
Deb made us regularly change our position in the gallery as a replacement for physically changing our position in the room! It was cute and a fun way to resemble an in-person workshop.
Although it would have been better to see everyone in person, the class being a writing class was conducive towards online learning.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you're good at/want to become better at self-motivation, this course is a great challenge. It requires you to organize and motivate creative work outside of class when your main responsibility is to yourself. As Deb says, "this one's for you."
Absolutely. Deb is perhaps the most caring teacher I've ever had. What a joy to get to be creative and to be supported creatively and emotionally throughout the semester.
Absolutely, but only if you really want to write something. You dont need to know what story you want to write, but you do need to be open to writing & finding the story within yourself.

I would definitely recommend this course to anyone who has any interest in creative writing or playwriting.  I learned so much and developed an incredible amount considering the short time we had together.

Yes!!! Take this course if you're at all interested in plays. You'll build a basic familiarity with some plays and get to make your own! If you need more clear, regular feedback or structure, this course probably isn't for you, but if you want to just be creative and let inspiration come, go for it!
YES!!! If you are passionate and interested in writing a play, 100% TAKE IT!!!
I would definitely recommend this course to another student! Professor Margolin was awesome, and class was always super fun and engaging!
